data.text: Carbon Gravel Wheel Set with Straight Pull Spokes

Hello. I am considering a carbon gravel wheel set that has straight pull spokes. I am a little concerned about them causing a problem out on a long ride. Any opinions out there if I should steer clear of straight spoke versus J Bend for real world serviceability? Thanks
Ive been running a straight spoke wheel set from 2005. Hasn't given me any issues.
data.author: Andrew Huff

data.text: I think reputable wheels with straight spokes are as serviceable as any spoke, in the field, ie not serviceable. But reliable.
data.author: Lee Duncan

data.text: No idea what in-the-field problem you are concerned about. With the carbon rim or the SP spokes? My gravel rear has a DT alloy rim and Sapim X-ray straight pulls, no problems so far. Spoke head spinning so you can't tighten the nipples could be a problem for field adjustment with *round* SP spokes, but field adjustment should only happen in the case of catastrophic damage needing a kludge/bodge fix in order to get home. Maybe an issue for expedition-level gravelling.
data.author: Mark Janeba

data.text: My carbon wheelset that I use for gravel/singletrack has straight pull spokes. I'm 220lbs, I do small jumps on these wheels and have never had an issue. Serviceability is a little better in my opinion as long as you can get to the spoke hole. NDS side on rear wheels are actually replaceable without having to remove the cassette. Similarly, you can replace spokes without having to remove the disc.
data.author: Drew Downing

data.text: Straight pull spokes are stronger than J bend spokes AND more easily serviced in the field. You can replace and straight pull spoke without having to remove cassette or brake rotors. Straight pull spokes do require an additional tool to keep them from spinning. And that tool is smaller and simpler for bladed spokes.
data.author: Mike Leland

data.text: Bring extras. You can tape them under your chainstay and not have to worry about finding them in other countries
data.author: Darrin Filer

data.text: sorry, I left some important details out. I am 250lbs. My current wheels are 28 hole aluminum wheels with standard J spokes. The wheels I am considering are 24 hole carbon. These carbon wheels have no weight limit. From what I have read, there are multiple lengths of straight pull spokes used on the carbon set. My concern was, with an already lower spoke count, Will I find these spokes in the wild should one of mine pop? Only because the J bend are far more common at most bike shops.
data.author: Bob Smith

data.text: my concern would be 250lbs and only 24 spoke wheels. Saving a few grams with a reduced spoke count wheel is not something I would consider at 250lbs. You won‚Äôt find any spokes in the wild straight or J
